segment.source: Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic
segment.target: Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) includes many asynchronous APIs to ensure that your app remains responsive when it does work that might take an extended amount of time.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) includes many asynchronous APIs to ensure that your app remains responsive when it does work that might take an extended amount of time.

segment.source: Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic
segment.target: Call asynchronous APIs in C# or Visual Basic

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) includes many asynchronous APIs to ensure that your app remains responsive when it does work that might take an extended amount of time.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) includes many asynchronous APIs to ensure that your app remains responsive when it does work that might take an extended amount of time.

segment.source: This topic discusses how to use asynchronous methods from the UWP in C# or Microsoft Visual Basic.
segment.target: This topic discusses how to use asynchronous methods from the UWP in C# or Microsoft Visual Basic.

segment.source: Asynchronous APIs keep your app from waiting for large operations to complete before continuing execution.
segment.target: Asynchronous APIs keep your app from waiting for large operations to complete before continuing execution.

segment.source: For example, an app that downloads info from the Internet might spend several seconds waiting for the info to arrive.
segment.target: For example, an app that downloads info from the Internet might spend several seconds waiting for the info to arrive.

segment.source: If you use a synchronous method to retrieve the info, the app is blocked until the method returns.
segment.target: If you use a synchronous method to retrieve the info, the app is blocked until the method returns.

segment.source: The app won't respond to user interaction and because it seems non-responsive, the user might become frustrated.
segment.target: The app won't respond to user interaction and because it seems non-responsive, the user might become frustrated.

segment.source: By providing asynchronous APIs, the UWP helps to ensure that your app stays responsive to the user when it's performing long operations.
segment.target: By providing asynchronous APIs, the UWP helps to ensure that your app stays responsive to the user when it's performing long operations.

segment.source: Most of the asynchronous APIs in the UWP don't have synchronous counterparts, so you need to be sure to understand how to use the asynchronous APIs with C# or Visual Basic in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.
segment.target: Most of the asynchronous APIs in the UWP don't have synchronous counterparts, so you need to be sure to understand how to use the asynchronous APIs with C# or Visual Basic in your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app.

segment.source: Here we show how to call asynchronous APIs of the UWP.
segment.target: Here we show how to call asynchronous APIs of the UWP.

segment.source: Using asynchronous APIs
segment.target: Using asynchronous APIs

segment.source: By convention, asynchronous methods are given names that end in "Async".
segment.target: By convention, asynchronous methods are given names that end in "Async".

segment.source: You typically call asynchronous APIs in response to a user's action, such as when the user clicks a button.
segment.target: You typically call asynchronous APIs in response to a user's action, such as when the user clicks a button.

segment.source: Calling an asynchronous method in an event handler is one of the simplest ways of using asynchronous APIs.
segment.target: Calling an asynchronous method in an event handler is one of the simplest ways of using asynchronous APIs.

segment.source: Here we use the await operator as an example.
segment.target: Here we use the await operator as an example.

segment.source: Suppose that you have an app that lists the titles of blog posts from a certain location.
segment.target: Suppose that you have an app that lists the titles of blog posts from a certain location.

segment.source: The app has a Button that the user clicks to get the titles.
segment.target: The app has a Button that the user clicks to get the titles.

segment.source: The titles are displayed in a TextBlock.
segment.target: The titles are displayed in a TextBlock.

segment.source: When the user clicks the button, it is important that the app remains responsive while it waits for the info from the blog's website.
segment.target: When the user clicks the button, it is important that the app remains responsive while it waits for the info from the blog's website.

segment.source: To ensure this responsiveness, the UWP provides an asynchronous method, SyndicationClient.RetrieveFeedAsync, to download the feed.
segment.target: To ensure this responsiveness, the UWP provides an asynchronous method, SyndicationClient.RetrieveFeedAsync, to download the feed.

segment.source: The example here gets the lists of blog posts from a blog by calling the asynchronous method, SyndicationClient.RetrieveFeedAsync, and awaiting the result.
segment.target: The example here gets the lists of blog posts from a blog by calling the asynchronous method, SyndicationClient.RetrieveFeedAsync, and awaiting the result.

segment.source: There are a couple of important things about this example.
segment.target: There are a couple of important things about this example.

segment.source: First, the line, uses the await operator with the call to the asynchronous method, RetrieveFeedAsync.
segment.target: First, the line, uses the await operator with the call to the asynchronous method, RetrieveFeedAsync.

segment.source: You can think of the await operator as telling the compiler that you are calling an asynchronous method, which causes the compiler to do some extra work so you don’t have to.
segment.target: You can think of the await operator as telling the compiler that you are calling an asynchronous method, which causes the compiler to do some extra work so you don’t have to.

segment.source: Next, the declaration of the event handler includes the keyword async.
segment.target: Next, the declaration of the event handler includes the keyword async.

segment.source: You must include this keyword in the method declaration of any method in which you use the await operator.
segment.target: You must include this keyword in the method declaration of any method in which you use the await operator.

segment.source: In this topic, we won't go into a lot of the details of what the compiler does with the await operator, but let's examine what your app does so that it is asynchronous and responsive.
segment.target: In this topic, we won't go into a lot of the details of what the compiler does with the await operator, but let's examine what your app does so that it is asynchronous and responsive.

segment.source: Consider what happens when you use synchronous code.
segment.target: Consider what happens when you use synchronous code.

segment.source: For example, suppose that there is a method called that is synchronous.
segment.target: For example, suppose that there is a method called that is synchronous.

segment.source: (There is no such method, but imagine that there is.) If your app included the line , instead of , execution of the app would stop until the return value of is available.
segment.target: (There is no such method, but imagine that there is.) If your app included the line , instead of , execution of the app would stop until the return value of is available.

segment.source: And while your app waits for the method to complete, it can't respond to any other events, such another Click event.
segment.target: And while your app waits for the method to complete, it can't respond to any other events, such another Click event.

segment.source: That is, your app would be blocked until returns.
segment.target: That is, your app would be blocked until returns.

segment.source: But if you call , the method initiates the retrieval and immediately returns.
segment.target: But if you call , the method initiates the retrieval and immediately returns.

segment.source: When you use await with RetrieveFeedAsync, the app temporarily exits the event handler.
segment.target: When you use await with RetrieveFeedAsync, the app temporarily exits the event handler.

segment.source: Then it can process other events while RetrieveFeedAsync executes asynchronously.
segment.target: Then it can process other events while RetrieveFeedAsync executes asynchronously.

segment.source: This keeps the app responsive to the user.
segment.target: This keeps the app responsive to the user.

segment.source: When RetrieveFeedAsync completes and the SyndicationFeed is available, the app essentially reenters the event handler where it left off, after , and finishes the rest of the method.
segment.target: When RetrieveFeedAsync completes and the SyndicationFeed is available, the app essentially reenters the event handler where it left off, after , and finishes the rest of the method.

segment.source: The nice thing about using the await operator is that the code doesn't look much different from how the code looks if you used the imaginary method.
segment.target: The nice thing about using the await operator is that the code doesn't look much different from how the code looks if you used the imaginary method.

segment.source: There are ways to write asynchronous code in C# or Visual Basic without the await operator, but the resulting code tends to emphasize the mechanics of executing asynchronously.
segment.target: There are ways to write asynchronous code in C# or Visual Basic without the await operator, but the resulting code tends to emphasize the mechanics of executing asynchronously.

segment.source: This makes asynchronous code hard to write, hard to understand, and hard to maintain.
segment.target: This makes asynchronous code hard to write, hard to understand, and hard to maintain.

segment.source: By using the await operator, you get the benefits of an asynchronous app without making your code complex.
segment.target: By using the await operator, you get the benefits of an asynchronous app without making your code complex.

segment.source: Return types and results of asynchronous APIs
segment.target: Return types and results of asynchronous APIs

segment.source: If you followed the link to RetrieveFeedAsync, you might have noticed that the return type of RetrieveFeedAsync is not a SyndicationFeed.
segment.target: If you followed the link to RetrieveFeedAsync, you might have noticed that the return type of RetrieveFeedAsync is not a SyndicationFeed.

segment.source: Instead, the return type is .
segment.target: Instead, the return type is .

segment.source: Viewed from the raw syntax, an asynchronous API returns an object that contains the result within it.
segment.target: Viewed from the raw syntax, an asynchronous API returns an object that contains the result within it.

segment.source: While it is common, and sometimes useful, to think of an asynchronous method as being awaitable, the await operator actually operates on the method’s return value, not on the method.
segment.target: While it is common, and sometimes useful, to think of an asynchronous method as being awaitable, the await operator actually operates on the method’s return value, not on the method.

segment.source: When you apply the await operator, what you get back is the result of calling GetResult on the object returned by the method.
segment.target: When you apply the await operator, what you get back is the result of calling GetResult on the object returned by the method.

segment.source: In the example, the SyndicationFeed is the result of RetrieveFeedAsync.GetResult().
segment.target: In the example, the SyndicationFeed is the result of RetrieveFeedAsync.GetResult().

segment.source: When you use an asynchronous method, you can examine the signature to see what you’ll get back after awaiting the value returned from the method.
segment.target: When you use an asynchronous method, you can examine the signature to see what you’ll get back after awaiting the value returned from the method.

segment.source: All asynchronous APIs in the UWP return one of the following types:
segment.target: All asynchronous APIs in the UWP return one of the following types:

segment.source: IAsyncOperationTResult
segment.target: IAsyncOperationTResult

segment.source: IAsyncOperationWithProgressTResult, TProgress
segment.target: IAsyncOperationWithProgressTResult, TProgress

segment.source: IAsyncAction
segment.target: IAsyncAction

segment.source: IAsyncActionWithProgressTProgress
segment.target: IAsyncActionWithProgressTProgress

segment.source: The result type of an asynchronous method is the same as the type parameter.
segment.target: The result type of an asynchronous method is the same as the type parameter.

segment.source: Types without a don't have a result.
segment.target: Types without a don't have a result.

segment.source: You can think of the result as being void.
segment.target: You can think of the result as being void.

segment.source: In Visual Basic, a Sub procedure is equivalent to a method with a void return type.
segment.target: In Visual Basic, a Sub procedure is equivalent to a method with a void return type.

segment.source: The table here gives examples of asynchronous methods and lists the return type and result type of each.
segment.target: The table here gives examples of asynchronous methods and lists the return type and result type of each.

segment.target: Asynchronous method

segment.target: Return type

segment.target: Result type

segment.target: SyndicationClient.RetrieveFeedAsync

segment.target: IAsyncOperationWithProgressSyndicationFeed, RetrievalProgress

segment.source: SyndicationFeed
segment.target: SyndicationFeed

segment.source: FileOpenPicker.PickSingleFileAsync
segment.target: FileOpenPicker.PickSingleFileAsync

segment.source: IAsyncOperationStorageFile
segment.target: IAsyncOperationStorageFile

segment.source: StorageFile
segment.target: StorageFile

segment.source: XmlDocument.SaveToFileAsync
segment.target: XmlDocument.SaveToFileAsync

segment.source: IAsyncAction
segment.target: IAsyncAction

segment.source: void
segment.target: void

segment.source: InkStrokeContainer.LoadAsync
segment.target: InkStrokeContainer.LoadAsync

segment.source: IAsyncActionWithProgressUInt64
segment.target: IAsyncActionWithProgressUInt64

segment.source: void
segment.target: void

segment.source: DataReader.LoadAsync
segment.target: DataReader.LoadAsync

segment.source: DataReaderLoadOperation, a custom results class that implements IAsyncOperationUInt32
segment.target: DataReaderLoadOperation, a custom results class that implements IAsyncOperationUInt32

segment.source: UInt32
segment.target: UInt32

segment.source: Asynchronous methods that are defined in .NET for UWP apps have the return type Task or TaskTResult.
segment.target: Asynchronous methods that are defined in .NET for UWP apps have the return type Task or TaskTResult.

segment.source: Methods that return Task are similar to the asynchronous methods in the UWP that return IAsyncAction.
segment.target: Methods that return Task are similar to the asynchronous methods in the UWP that return IAsyncAction.

segment.source: In each case, the result of the asynchronous method is void.
segment.target: In each case, the result of the asynchronous method is void.

segment.source: The return type TaskTResult is similar to IAsyncOperationTResult in that the result of the asynchronous method when running the task is the same type as the type parameter.
segment.target: The return type TaskTResult is similar to IAsyncOperationTResult in that the result of the asynchronous method when running the task is the same type as the type parameter.

segment.source: For more info about using .NET for UWP apps and tasks, see .NET for Windows Runtime apps overview.
segment.target: For more info about using .NET for UWP apps and tasks, see .NET for Windows Runtime apps overview.

segment.source: Handling errors
segment.target: Handling errors

segment.source: When you use the await operator to retrieve your results from an asynchronous method, you can use a try/catch block to handle errors that occur in asynchronous methods, just as you do for synchronous methods.
segment.target: When you use the await operator to retrieve your results from an asynchronous method, you can use a try/catch block to handle errors that occur in asynchronous methods, just as you do for synchronous methods.

segment.source: The previous example wraps the RetrieveFeedAsync method and await operation in a try/catch block to handle errors when an exception is thrown.
segment.target: The previous example wraps the RetrieveFeedAsync method and await operation in a try/catch block to handle errors when an exception is thrown.

segment.source: When asynchronous methods call other asynchronous methods, any asynchronous method that results in an exception will be propagated to the outer methods.
segment.target: When asynchronous methods call other asynchronous methods, any asynchronous method that results in an exception will be propagated to the outer methods.

segment.source: This means that you can put a try/catch block on the outer-most method to catch errors for the nested asynchronous methods.
segment.target: This means that you can put a try/catch block on the outer-most method to catch errors for the nested asynchronous methods.

segment.source: Again, this is similar to how you catch exceptions for synchronous methods.
segment.target: Again, this is similar to how you catch exceptions for synchronous methods.

segment.source: However, you can't use await in the catch block.
segment.target: However, you can't use await in the catch block.

segment.source: Tip Starting with C# in Microsoft Visual Studio 2005, you can use await in the catch block.
segment.target: Tip Starting with C# in Microsoft Visual Studio 2005, you can use await in the catch block.

segment.source: Summary and next steps
segment.target: Summary and next steps

segment.source: The pattern of calling an asynchronous method that we show here is the simplest one to use when you call asynchronous APIs in an event handler.
segment.target: The pattern of calling an asynchronous method that we show here is the simplest one to use when you call asynchronous APIs in an event handler.

segment.source: You can also use this pattern when you call an asynchronous method in an overridden method that returns void or a Sub in Visual Basic.
segment.target: You can also use this pattern when you call an asynchronous method in an overridden method that returns void or a Sub in Visual Basic.

segment.source: As you encounter asynchronous methods in the UWP, it is important to remember:
segment.target: As you encounter asynchronous methods in the UWP, it is important to remember:

segment.source: By convention, asynchronous methods are given names that end in "Async".
segment.target: By convention, asynchronous methods are given names that end in "Async".

segment.source: Any method that uses the await operator must have its declaration marked with the async keyword.
segment.target: Any method that uses the await operator must have its declaration marked with the async keyword.

segment.source: When an app finds the await operator, the app remains responsive to user interaction while the asynchronous method executes.
segment.target: When an app finds the await operator, the app remains responsive to user interaction while the asynchronous method executes.

segment.source: Awaiting the value returned by an asynchronous method returns an object that contains the result.
segment.target: Awaiting the value returned by an asynchronous method returns an object that contains the result.

segment.source: In most cases, the result contained within the return value is what's useful, not the return value itself.
segment.target: In most cases, the result contained within the return value is what's useful, not the return value itself.

segment.source: You can find the type of the value that is contained inside the result by looking at the return type of the async method.
segment.target: You can find the type of the value that is contained inside the result by looking at the return type of the async method.

segment.source: Using asynchronous APIs and async patterns is often a way to improve the responsiveness of your app.
segment.target: Using asynchronous APIs and async patterns is often a way to improve the responsiveness of your app.

segment.target: The example in this topic outputs text that looks like this.
